Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Gendered Transnational Labor Migration, Agriculture, and Environmental Change in Mesoamerica

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Labor migration across international borders continues to grow and is an increasingly important livelihood strategy for many households around the world. This type of migration has significant implications for rural livelihoods and the physical environments of migrant-sending communities, particularly in the developing world. It is predicted that global environmental change will result in increased out-migration from rural areas in the developing world as livelihoods are impacted. Migration patterns (who goes, where, and for how long) are highly gendered, with men and women following different strategies in different places. Labor migrants usually maintain ties to origin households and communities by frequently sending remittances and by returning home periodically or permanently. Thus their migration is associated both with their physical absence and with the injection of new resources, ideas, or skills during their absence and on their return. This research will examine the interconnected outcomes of international labor migration for sending region agricultural systems, land distributions, household economies, gender relations, and local/regional environments in Mexico and Central America. Research to date in Mexico suggests that local gender norms and expectations are important in shaping these outcomes. Thus this project will explicitly explore the role of gender, and specific and varying gendered migration patterns, in determining the impacts of international labor migration. The project will also analyze what role local environmental change plays as a driver of current patterns (both internal and international) of labor migration. By examining both environmental outcomes and environmental drivers, research results will contribute to a better theoretical understanding of the relationship between environmental change and human migration and the complex intertwining of this relationship with key social systems such as gender. Over a five-year period, the research supported by this CAREER award will conduct research in three regions: Mexico's southern Yucatan region, the highland Guatemalan state of Huehuetenango, and the northern Nicaraguan states of Leon and Chinandega. Methods are primarily ethnographic, consisting of face-to-face interview-surveys with smallholder farming households as well as semi-structured in-depth interviews with a subset of migration-participating households.

Findings from this project will inform policies to facilitate positive outcomes in human and environmental well-being in the contemporary world. The project will help establish a Geographers' Migration Research Network. Integrated with the research project are various educational activities. The project will support and train at least three graduate students through research assistantships and their participation in collaborative research teams consisting of faculty and students from Utah State University and El Colegio de la Frontera Sur in Mexico. Establishment of these research teams will foster an expectation and culture of international collaboration. The project will also foster global and local citizenship in undergraduate students, through service-learning activities and the development, implementation, assessment, and dissemination of new teaching materials on migration, environment, and development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The funded project investigated the relationship between international out-migration and environmental change in poor, small-scale farming communities at case-study research sites in Nicaragua and Guatemala. Research questions focused both on the nature of environmental change as a driver of international migration and on the subsequent effects of such migration on agricultural land use. Researchers paid particular attention to the mediating roles of social institutions and relations in the studied migration-environment processes and to how migration and its effects are gendered, i.e. different for men and women.

The resultant research has improved our understanding of how environmental changes shape the behavior of members of small-scale farming households in these two countries, with respect to labor migration to neighboring countries and to the United States. At some of the sites, drought incidence and overall decreasing rainfall has made farming more difficult, but the larger socioeconomic context plays a critical role in how these changes translate into livelihood impacts. Researchers uncovered the important roles played by national and local land tenure systems and land inequalities, lack of credit availability, and absent national policies and practices supportive of small-scale and semi-subsistence agricultural production. Household strategies for achieving food security and for purchasing farming inputs and renting land emerged as a central considerations in migration behavior.

Research findings also demonstrated that household participation in labor migration did not change markedly small-scale farmers' land-use activities, and in many cases, allowed small-scale farming to persist. In addition, inequalities between men and women, in terms of agricultural decision making and asset control, appear to have been moderated through household engagement in labor migration in several of the cases examined.

Accompanying research in Mexico, in the Yucatan peninsula where labor migration also has been an aspect of many small-scale farming households' activities, examined the intervening role of Mexico's central anti-poverty program ("Prospera") in semi-subsistence farming and in women's changing positions in small, farming communities. Additional student-led research in these communities focused on farming families' varied experiences of climate change vulnerability, on changing social relations and intra-community resource conflict, on the impacts of food security programs and policies on semi-subsistence farming and food consumption, and on the identified effects of changing climate on rain-fed maize yields in concert with current policies for small-scale agricultural production.

The project fully or partially supported research training for a postdoctoral research fellow and degree completion for five graduate students. The project additionally supported the participation of an undergraduate researcher in field data collection and in data analysis. Supported teaching-related activities included pedagogical assessment of service-learning approaches employed in the principal investigator's university teaching. Other broader impacts of the funded project included the engagement of the public in science through the presentation and discussion of research findings in the research communities and, most importantly, the relevance of the research findings to pressing intersecting social issues of hunger, small-scale farming, climate change, and human migration.
